column1: 175;Brazil (1985);"The period of Brazilian history since 1985 corresponds to the contemporary epoch in the history of Brazil
column2: since the end of the military regime that had ruled the country from 1964 until 1985 and the restoration of civilian government.

column1: In January 1985 the process of negotiated transition towards democracy reached its climax with the election of Tancredo Neves of the PMDB party (the party that had always opposed the military regime)
column2: as the first civilian president since 1964.

column1: Neves' election to succeed general Figueiredo
column2: the last of the military hand-picked Presidents

column4: that contrasts with the term República Velha (or Old Republic
column5: the name of the first epoch of the Brazilian Republic
column6: that lasted from 1889 until 1930)
column7: became synonym with the contemporary phase of the Brazilian Republic
column8: that is
column9: with the political institutions established in the wake of the country's re-democratization.

column1: The first phase of the Brazilian New Republic
column2: from the inauguration of José Sarney in 1985 (President Tancredo Neves fell ill on the eve of his inauguration so that he could not attend it; his running-mate José Sarney was inaugurated as vice president and served in Tancredo's stead as acting president until Tancredo died
column3: without having ever taken the oath of office
column4: whereupon Sarney succeeded to the presidency) until the inauguration of Fernando Collor in 1990 can be considered a still transitional period because
column5: while the 1967–1969 constitution still remained in force the executive still had enormous powers and the president was able to legislate by means of decree-laws.

column1: In 1986 the Sarney government fulfilled Tancredo's promise of passing in Congress a Constitutional Amendment to the Constitution inherited from the military period
column2: summoning elections for a National Constituent Assembly to draft and adopt a new Constitution for the country. The Constituent Assembly began deliberations in February 1987 and concluded its work on October 5

column1: The adoption of Brazil's current Constitution in 1988 completed the process of re-establishment of the democratic institutions. The new Constitution replaced the authoritarian legislation that still remained in place and that had been inherited from the days of the military regime.
In 1989 the first elections for president by direct popular ballot since the military coup of 1964 were held under the new Constitution
column2: and Fernando Collor was elected. Collor was inaugurated on March 15
column3: 1990. With the inauguration of the first president elected under the 1988 Constitution
column4: the last step in the long process of democratization took place
column5: and the phase of transition was finally over.

column1: Since then
column2: six presidential terms have elapsed
column3: without rupture to the constitutional order: the first term corresponded to the Collor and Franco administrations (Collor was impeached on charges of corruption in 1992 and resigned the presidency
column4: being succeeded by Franco
column5: his vice president); the second and third terms corresponded to the Fernando Henrique Cardoso Administration; in the fourth and fifth presidential terms Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva served as President; and the sixth term is equivalent to Dilma Rousseff's first administration. In 2015

column1: 229;Star Trek III: The Search for Spock (1984);"Star Trek III: The Search for Spock is a 1984 American science fiction film directed by Leonard Nimoy and based on the television series of the same name created by Gene Roddenberry. It is the third film in the Star Trek film series

Aside from a single day of location shooting

column1: 230;Star Trek IV: The Voyage Home (1986);"Star Trek IV: The Voyage Home is a 1986 American science fiction film released by Paramount Pictures. It is the fourth feature film based on Star Trek

Few of the humpback whales in the film were real: ILM devised full-size animatronics and small motorized models to stand in for the real creatures.

column1: 253;Pillow Book
column2: The (1995);"Phonetic pillows are pillows made in the various shapes of the symbols of the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA). They are used in the teaching of phonetics and speech
column3: primarily in theatre departments in higher education. Dozens of theatre programs have used Phonetic Pillows
column4: including Boston University
column5: North Carolina School of the Arts
column6: Cincinnati Conservatory University of Washington Seattle
column7: Yale School of Drama
column8: Columbia University
column9: University of Pretoria
column10: South Africa
column11: and The Central School of Speech and Drama
column13: UK. Phonetic pillows were invented and introduced by Louis Colaianni.

column1: In her book Freeing the Natural Voice
column2: renowned voice coach and teacher Kristin Linklater comments on phonetic pillows as introduced in the book The Joy of Phonetics and Accents saying
column3: ”Colaianni has developed ways of extending freedom and sensuality from voice into speech so that one need no longer divide voicing from speaking.”

column1: Phonetic pillows are recognized as a tool for Student-centered learning. In the book Student-Centered Learning Online and On Ground
column2: Sarah D'Angelo states
column3: ""Colaianni's method in particular revolutionized teaching and learning of the IPA with his pedagogical infusion of a post modern art form: soft sculpture. The use of large
column4: soft
column5: colorful
column6: three-dimensional IPA shapes
column7: or ""pillows"" as he calls them
column8: represent each of the phonetic symbols used in spoken American English.""

column1: Phonetic Pillows represent a move to connect the kinesthetic – fabric
column2: texture
column3: the simple act of throwing and receiving the pillow – with an intensified visual component ...""

column1: --Robert Barton
column2: ""The Vocal Vision
column3: (Applause

column1: ^ Colaianni
column2: Louis. ""About Phonetic Pillows"". www.joyofphonetics.com. Retrieved 27 September 2016."

column1: 292;Rosewood (1997);"The Rosewood massacre was a violent
column2: racially motivated massacre of blacks and destruction of a black town that took place during the first week of January 1923 in rural Levy County
column3: Florida. At least six blacks and two whites were killed
column4: and the town of Rosewood was abandoned and destroyed in what contemporary news reports characterized as a race riot. Racial disturbances were common during the early 20th century in the United States
column5: reflecting the nation's rapid social changes. Florida had an especially high number of lynchings of black males in the years before the massacre
column6: including a well-publicized incident in December 1922.

column1: Prior to the massacre
column2: the town of Rosewood had been a quiet
column3: primarily black
column4: self-sufficient whistle stop on the Seaboard Air Line Railway. Trouble began when white men from several nearby towns lynched a black Rosewood resident because of unsupported accusations that a white woman in nearby Sumner had been beaten and possibly raped by a black drifter. When the town's black citizens rallied together to defend themselves against further attacks
column5: a mob of several hundred whites combed the countryside hunting for black people
column6: and burned almost every structure in Rosewood. Survivors from the town hid for several days in nearby swamps until they were evacuated by train and car to larger towns. Although state and local authorities were aware of the violence
column7: no arrests were made for what happened in Rosewood. The town was abandoned by its former black residents; none ever moved back.

column1: Although the rioting was widely reported around the United States at the time
column2: few official records documented the event. Survivors
column3: their descendants
column4: and the perpetrators remained silent about Rosewood for decades. Sixty years after the rioting
column5: the story of Rosewood was revived in major media when several journalists covered it in the early 1980s. Survivors and their descendants organized to sue the state for having failed to protect Rosewood's black community. In 1993
column6: the Florida Legislature commissioned a report on the massacre. As a result of the findings
column7: Florida became the first U.S. state to compensate survivors and their descendants for damages incurred because of racial violence. The incident was the subject of a 1997 feature film directed by John Singleton. In 2004
column8: the state designated the site of Rosewood as a Florida Heritage Landmark. Officially
column9: the recorded death toll of the first week of January 1923 was six blacks and two whites. Historians disagree about this number. Some survivors' stories claim there may have been up to 27 black residents killed
column10: and assert that newspapers did not report the total number of white deaths. Minnie Lee Langley
column11: who was in the Carrier house siege
column12: recalls that she stepped over many white bodies on the porch when she left the house. Several eyewitnesses claim to have seen a mass grave filled with black people; one remembers a plow brought from Cedar Key that covered 26 bodies. Others claimed as many as 150 people were killed. However
column13: by the time authorities investigated these claims
column14: most of the witnesses were dead
column15: or too elderly and infirm to lead them to a site to confirm the stories."

column1: 344;Apostle
column2: The (1997);"In Christian theology and ecclesiology
column3: the apostles (Greek: ἀπόστολος
column4: translit. apóstolos
column5: lit. 'one who is sent away')
column6: particularly the Twelve Apostles (also called the Twelve Disciples)
column7: were the primary historical disciples of Jesus
column8: the central figure in Christianity. During the life and ministry of Jesus in the 1st century AD
column9: the apostles were his closest followers and became the primary teachers of the gospel message of Jesus. The word disciple is sometimes used interchangeably with apostle; for instance
column10: the Gospel of John makes no distinction between the two terms. In modern usage
column11: prominent missionaries are often called apostles
column12: a practice which stems from the Latin equivalent of apostle
column14: the source of the English word missionary. For example
column15: Saint Patrick (AD 373–463) was the ""Apostle of Ireland""
column16: and Saint Boniface (680–755) was the ""Apostle to the Germans"".

column1: While Christian tradition often refers to the apostles as being 12 in number
column2: different gospel writers give different names for the same individual
column3: and apostles mentioned in one gospel are not mentioned in others. The commissioning of the Twelve Apostles during the ministry of Jesus is recorded in the Synoptic Gospels. After his resurrection
column4: Jesus sent 11 of them (minus Judas Iscariot
column5: who by then had died) by the Great Commission to spread his teachings to all nations. This event is commonly called the Dispersion of the Apostles. There is also an Eastern Christian tradition derived from the Gospel of Luke of there having been as many as 70 apostles during the time of Jesus' ministry. Prominent figures in early Christianity
column6: notably Paul
column7: were often called apostles
column8: even though their ministry or mission came after the life of Jesus.

column1: The period of early Christianity during the lifetimes of the apostles is called the Apostolic Age. During the 1st century AD
column2: the apostles established churches throughout the territories of the Roman Empire and
column3: according to tradition
column4: through the Middle East
column5: Africa
column6: and India.

column1: Although not one of the apostles commissioned during the life of Jesus
column2: Paul
column3: a Jew named Saul of Tarsus
column4: claimed a special commission from the resurrected Jesus and is considered ""the apostle of the Gentiles""
column5: [Romans 11:13] for his missions to spread the gospel message after his conversion. In his writings
column6: the epistles to Christian churches throughout the Levant
column7: Paul did not restrict the term ""apostle"" to the Twelve
column8: and often refers to his mentor Barnabas as an apostle. The restricted usage appears in the Revelation to John.

column1: By the 2nd century AD
column2: association with the apostles was esteemed as an evidence of authority. Churches which are believed to have been founded by one of the apostles are known as apostolic sees. Paul's epistles were accepted as scripture
column3: and two of the four canonical gospels were associated with apostles
column4: as were other New Testament works. Various Christian texts
column5: such as the Didache and the Apostolic Constitutions
column6: were attributed to the apostles. Bishops traced their lines of succession back to individual apostles
column7: who were said to have dispersed from Jerusalem and established churches across great territories. Christian bishops have traditionally claimed authority deriving
column8: by apostolic succession
column9: from the Twelve. Early Church Fathers who came to be associated with apostles
column10: such as Pope Clement I with St. Peter
column11: are referred to as the Apostolic Fathers. The Apostles' Creed
column13: was said to have been composed by the apostles themselves."

column1: 502;Bananas (1971);"The banana is an edible fruit – botanically a berry – produced by several kinds of large herbaceous flowering plants in the genus Musa. In some countries

column1: The term ""banana"" is also used as the common name for the plants which produce the fruit. This can extend to other members of the genus Musa like the scarlet banana (Musa coccinea)

column1: 719;Canadian Bacon (1994);"Bacon is a meat product prepared from cured pork. It is first cured using large quantities of salt

column9: especially game

column1: In Fast
column2: Cheap & Out of Control

column2: ""cheap
column3: and ""reliable

column5: the robot scientist from MIT

column8: replacing the need for reliability with chance and sheer numbers

column1: 1026;Lay of the Land
column2: The (1997);"Thomas Dale DeLay (/dəˈleɪ/; born April 8

column3: DeLay temporarily resigned from his position as House Majority Leader
column4: and later
column5: after pressure from fellow Republicans

column3: the Texas Court of Criminal Appeals affirmed the appellate court decision overturning DeLay's conviction.

column1: 1278;Selena (1997);"Selena Quintanilla-Pérez (Spanish: [seˈlena kintaˈniʝa ˈpeɾes] or [seˈlena kintaˈniʎa ˈpeɾeθ]; April 16
column2: 1971 – March 31
column3: 1995) was an American singer
column4: songwriter
column5: spokesperson
column6: model
column7: actress
column8: and fashion designer. Called the Queen of Tejano music
column9: her contributions to music and fashion made her one of the most celebrated Mexican-American entertainers of the late 20th century. Billboard magazine named her the ""top Latin artist of the '90s"" and the ""best selling Latin artist of the decade"". Media outlets called her the ""Tejano Madonna"" for her clothing choices. She also ranks among the most influential Latin artists of all-time and is credited for catapulting a music genre into the mainstream market.

column1: The youngest child of the Quintanilla family
column2: she debuted on the music scene in 1980 as a member of the band Selena y Los Dinos
column3: which also included her elder siblings A.B. Quintanilla and Suzette Quintanilla. Selena began recording professionally in 1982. In the 1980s
column4: she was often criticized and was refused bookings at venues across Texas for performing Tejano music—a male-dominated music genre. However
column5: her popularity grew after she won the Tejano Music Award for Female Vocalist of the Year in 1987
column6: which she won nine consecutive times. Selena signed with EMI Latin in 1989 and released her self-titled debut album the same year
column7: while her brother became her principal music producer and songwriter.

column1: Selena released Entre a Mi Mundo (1992)
column2: which peaked at number one on the U.S. Billboard Regional Mexican Albums chart for 19 nonconsecutive weeks. The album's commercial success led music critics to call the album the ""breakthrough"" recording of her musical career. One of its singles
column3: ""Como La Flor""
column4: became one of her most popular signature songs. Live! (1993) won Best Mexican/American Album at the 1994 Grammy Awards
column5: becoming the first recording by a Tejano artist to do so. In 1994
column6: Selena released Amor Prohibido
column7: which became one of the best-selling Latin albums in the United States. It was critically acclaimed as being responsible for Tejano music's first marketable era as it became one of the most popular Latin music subgenres at the time. Selena began recording English-language songs for her crossover album.

column1: Aside from music
column2: Selena was active in her community and donated her time to civic causes. Coca-Cola appointed her its spokesperson in Texas. Selena became a sex icon; she was often criticized for wearing suggestive outfits in light of her comments about being a role model for young women. Selena and her guitarist
column3: Chris Pérez
column4: eloped in April 1992 after her father raised concerns over their relationship. On March 31
column6: Selena was shot dead by Yolanda Saldívar
column7: her friend and former employee of her Selena Etc. boutiques. Saldívar was cornered by police when she attempted to flee
column8: and threatened to kill herself
column9: but was convinced to give herself up and was sentenced to life in prison with a possible parole after 30 years. Saldívar is currently incarcerated at the Mountain View Unit in Gatesville
column10: Texas. Two weeks later
column11: George W. Bush—governor of Texas at the time—declared Selena's birthday Selena Day in Texas. Her posthumous crossover album
column14: making Selena the first Latin artist to accomplish this feat. In 1997
column15: Warner Bros. released Selena
column16: a film about her life and career
column17: which starred Jennifer Lopez as Selena and Lupe Ontiveros as Saldívar. As of 2012
column18: Selena has sold over 60 million albums worldwide."

column1: 1346;Dingo (1992);"The dingo (Canis dingo or Canis lupus dingo) is a wild canine found in Australia whose taxonomic status as a distinct species remains debated. The dingo is the largest terrestrial predator in Australia

column2: it is listed as vulnerable to extinction. It is proposed that this is due to susceptibility to genetic pollution: a controversial concept according to which interbreeding with domestic dogs may dilute the dingo's unique adaptations to the Australian environment."

column1: 1354;Venice/Venice (1992);"Venice (English /ˈvɛnɪs/ VEN-iss; Italian: Venezia [veˈnɛtsja]; Venetian: Venesia [veˈnɛsja]) is a city in northeastern Italy and the capital of the Veneto region. It is situated across a group of 118 small islands that are separated by canals and linked by bridges. These are located in the shallow Venetian Lagoon
column2: an enclosed bay that lies between the mouths of the Po and the Piave Rivers. Parts of Venice are renowned for the beauty of their settings

column4: and artwork. The lagoon and a part of the city are listed as a World Heritage Site.

column1: The name is derived from the ancient Veneti people who inhabited the region by the 10th century BC. The city was historically the capital of the Republic of Venice. Venice has been known as the ""La Dominante
column2: ""Serenissima
column3: ""Queen of the Adriatic
column4: ""City of Water
column5: ""City of Masks
column6: ""City of Bridges
column7: ""The Floating City
column8: and ""City of Canals.""

column1: The Republic of Venice was a major financial and maritime power during the Middle Ages and Renaissance
column2: and a staging area for the Crusades and the Battle of Lepanto

column4: grain
column5: and spice) and art in the 13th century up to the end of the 17th century. The City State of Venice is considered to have been the first real international financial center which gradually emerged from the 9th century to its peak in the 14th century. This made Venice a wealthy city throughout most of its history.

column1: It is also known for its several important artistic movements
column2: especially the Renaissance period. After the Napoleonic Wars and the Congress of Vienna
column3: the Republic was annexed by the Austrian Empire
column4: until it became part of the Kingdom of Italy in 1866
column5: following a referendum held as a result of the Third Italian War of Independence. Venice has played an important role in the history of symphonic and operatic music
column6: and it is the birthplace of Antonio Vivaldi. Venice has been ranked the most beautiful city in the world as of 2016."

column2: The (1994);"Sexual slavery is slavery for the purpose of sexual exploitation. Sexual slavery may involve single-owner sexual slavery; ritual slavery

column7: concubines and their children had distinct rights and legitimate social positions.

column3: Virginia
column4: on 22 June 1807
column5: between the British warship HMS Leopard and the American frigate USS Chesapeake. The crew of Leopard pursued
column6: attacked
column7: and boarded the American frigate
column8: looking for deserters from the Royal Navy. Chesapeake was caught unprepared and after a short battle involving broadsides received from Leopard
column9: the commander of Chesapeake
column10: James Barron

column1: Four crew members were removed from the American vessel and were tried for desertion
column2: one of whom was subsequently hanged. Chesapeake was allowed to return home
column3: where James Barron was court martialed and suspended from command.

column1: The Chesapeake–Leopard Affair created an uproar among Americans. There were strident calls for war with Great Britain
column2: but these quickly subsided. President Thomas Jefferson initially attempted to use this widespread bellicosity to diplomatically threaten the British government into settling the matter. The United States Congress backed away from armed conflict when British envoys showed no contrition for the Chesapeake affair
column3: delivering proclamations reaffirming impressment. Jefferson's political failure to coerce Great Britain led him toward economic warfare: the Embargo of 1807.

column1: 1366;JLG/JLG - autoportrait de décembre (1994);"Jean-Luc Godard (French: [ʒɑ̃lyk ɡɔdaʁ]; born 3 December 1930) is a French-Swiss film director
column2: screenwriter and film critic. He is often identified with the 1960s French film movement La Nouvelle Vague
column3: or ""New Wave"".

column1: Like his New Wave contemporaries
column2: Godard criticized mainstream French cinema's ""Tradition of Quality""
column3: which ""emphasized craft over innovation
column4: privileged established directors over new directors
column5: and preferred the great works of the past to experimentation."" As a result of such argument
column6: he and like-minded critics started to make their own films. Many of Godard's films challenge the conventions of traditional Hollywood in addition to French cinema. He is often considered the most radical French filmmaker of the 1960s and 1970s; his approach in film conventions
column7: politics and philosophies made him arguably the most influential director of the French New Wave. Along with showing knowledge of film history through homages and references
column8: several of his films expressed his political views; he was an avid reader of existential and Marxist philosophy.

column1: Since the New Wave
column2: his politics have been much less radical and his recent films are about representation and human conflict from a humanist
column3: and a Marxist perspective.

column1: In a 2002 Sight & Sound poll
column2: Godard ranked third in the critics' top-ten directors of all time (which was put together by assembling the directors of the individual films for which the critics voted). He is said to have ""created one of the largest bodies of critical analysis of any filmmaker since the mid-twentieth century."" He and his work have been central to narrative theory and have ""challenged both commercial narrative cinema norms and film criticism's vocabulary."" In 2010
column3: Godard was awarded an Academy Honorary Award
column4: but did not attend the award ceremony.

column1: Godard's films have inspired many directors including Martin Scorsese
column2: Quentin Tarantino
column3: Brian De Palma
column4: Steven Soderbergh
column5: D. A. Pennebaker
column6: Robert Altman
column7: Jim Jarmusch

column10: Bernardo Bertolucci

column1: 1367;Faust (1994);"Faust is a 1994 film directed by Jan Švankmajer. It merges live-action footage with stop-motion footage and includes imaginative puppetry and claymation. column1: 1392;Locusts
column2: The (1997);"Locusts are certain species of short-horned grasshoppers in the family Acrididae that have a swarming phase. These insects are usually solitary
column3: but under certain circumstances
column4: become more abundant and change their behaviour and habits
column5: becoming gregarious. No taxonomic distinction is made between locust and grasshopper species; the basis for the definition is whether a species forms swarms under intermittently suitable conditions.

column1: In the solitary phase
column2: these grasshoppers are innocuous
column3: their numbers are low
column4: and they do not pose a major economic threat to agriculture. However
column5: under suitable conditions of drought followed by rapid vegetation growth
column6: serotonin in their brains triggers a dramatic set of changes: they start to breed abundantly
column7: becoming gregarious and nomadic (loosely described as migratory) when their populations become dense enough. They form bands of wingless nymphs which later become swarms of winged adults. Both the bands and the swarms move around and rapidly strip fields and cause damage to crops. The adults are powerful fliers; they can travel great distances
column8: consuming most of the green vegetation wherever the swarm settles.

column1: Locusts have formed plagues since prehistory. The Ancient Egyptians carved them on their tombs and the insects are mentioned in the Bible and the Quran. Swarms have devastated crops and been a contributory cause of famines and human migrations. More recently
column2: changes in agricultural practices and better surveillance of locations where swarms tend to originate
column3: have meant that control measures can be used at an early stage. The traditional means of control are based on the use of insecticides from the ground or the air
column4: but other methods using biological control are proving effective.

column1: Swarming behaviour has decreased in the 20th century
column2: but despite modern surveillance and control methods
column3: the potential for swarms to form is still present
column4: and when suitable climatic conditions occur and vigilance lapses
column5: plagues can still occur. Locusts are large insects and convenient for use in research and the study of zoology in the classroom. They are also edible insects; they have been eaten throughout history and are considered a delicacy in many countries. The word ""locust"" is derived from the Vulgar Latin locusta
column6: meaning locust or lobster."

column1: 1395;Hurricane Streets (1998);"The 1998 Atlantic hurricane season was one of the deadliest and costliest Atlantic hurricane seasons that featured the highest number of storm-related fatalities in over 200 years. It officially began on June 1 and ended on November 30

column11: 000 confirmed deaths and at least $6.2 billion (1998 USD) in damage. The season was the first since Hurricane Andrew in the 1992 season to feature a Category 5 hurricane on the Saffir–Simpson hurricane wind scale.

column1: Several storms made landfall or directly affected land. Hurricane Bonnie made landfall in southeastern North Carolina as a Category 2 hurricane in late August
column2: killing five people and causing about $1 billion in damage. Hurricane Earl caused $79 million in damage and three deaths after making landfall in Florida as a Category 1 hurricane. The two deadliest and most destructive hurricanes of the season
column3: Hurricane Georges and Mitch
column4: caused $9.72 billion in damage and $6.2 billion in damage
column5: respectively. Hurricane Georges was an intense Category 4 hurricane that moved through many of the Caribbean Islands
column6: causing significant damage before making landfall near Biloxi
column7: Mississippi. Hurricane Mitch was a very powerful and destructive late-season hurricane that affected much of Central America before making landfall in Florida as a tropical storm. The significant amount of rainfall that Mitch produced across Central America caused significant damage and killed at least 11
column8: 000 people
column9: making the system the second deadliest hurricane in recorded history
column10: behind only the Great Hurricane of 1780."

column1: 1492;Window to Paris (1994);"Window to Paris (Russian: Окно в Париж) is a 1993 Russian drama film directed by Yuri Mamin.

column1: 1493;Modern Affair
column2: A (1995);"The Dreyfus Affair (French: l'affaire Dreyfus
column3: pronounced: [la.fɛʁ dʁɛ.fys]) was a political scandal that divided the Third French Republic from 1894 until its resolution in 1906. The affair is often seen as a modern and universal symbol of injustice
column4: and it remains one of the most notable examples of a complex miscarriage of justice. The major role played by the press and public opinion proved influential in the lasting social conflict.

column1: The scandal began in December 1894
column2: with the treason conviction of Captain Alfred Dreyfus
column3: a young French artillery officer of Alsatian and Jewish descent. Sentenced to life imprisonment for allegedly communicating French military secrets to the German Embassy in Paris
column4: Dreyfus was imprisoned on Devil's Island in French Guiana
column5: where he spent nearly five years.

column1: Evidence came to light in 1896 — primarily through an investigation instigated by Georges Picquart
column2: head of counter-espionage — identifying a French Army major named Ferdinand Walsin Esterházy as the real culprit. After high-ranking military officials suppressed the new evidence
column3: a military court unanimously acquitted Esterházy after a trial lasting only two days. The Army then accused Dreyfus with additional charges based on falsified documents. Word of the military court's framing of Dreyfus and of an attempted cover-up began to spread
column4: chiefly owing to J'accuse
column5: a vehement open letter published in a Paris newspaper in January 1898 by famed writer Émile Zola. Activists put pressure on the government to reopen the case.

column2: Dreyfus was returned to France for another trial. The intense political and judicial scandal that ensued divided French society between those who supported Dreyfus (now called ""Dreyfusards"")
column3: such as Sarah Bernhardt
column4: Anatole France
column5: Henri Poincaré and Georges Clemenceau
column6: and those who condemned him (the anti-Dreyfusards)
column7: such as Édouard Drumont
column8: the director and publisher of the antisemitic newspaper La Libre Parole. The new trial resulted in another conviction and a 10-year sentence
column9: but Dreyfus was given a pardon and set free. Eventually all the accusations against Dreyfus were demonstrated to be baseless. In 1906 Dreyfus was exonerated and reinstated as a major in the French Army. He served during the whole of World War I
column10: ending his service with the rank of lieutenant-colonel. He died in 1935.

column1: The affair from 1894 to 1906 divided France deeply and lastingly into two opposing camps: the pro-Army
column2: mostly Catholic ""anti-Dreyfusards"" and the anticlerical
column3: pro-republican Dreyfusards. It embittered French politics and encouraged radicalization."

column1: 1519;New Jersey Drive (1995);"Route 208 is a state highway in the northern part of New Jersey in the United States. It runs 10.07 miles (16.21 km) from an interchange with Route 4 and County Route 79 (Saddle River Road) in Fair Lawn northwest to an interchange with Interstate 287 (I-287) in Oakland. The route runs through suburban areas of Bergen and Passaic counties as four- to six-lane divided highway. It is constructed like a freeway
column2: as intersections with cross roads are controlled by interchanges
column3: but is not a controlled access road as several driveways exist. The route runs through the communities of Fair Lawn
column4: Glen Rock
column5: Hawthorne
column6: Wyckoff
column7: and Franklin Lakes along the way
column8: interchanging with County Route 507 (CR 507) in Fair Lawn and CR 502 in Franklin Lakes.

column1: What is now Route 208 was initially planned as Route S4B in 1929
column2: a spur of Route 4 that was to run from Fair Lawn northwest to the New York border in Greenwood Lake
column3: where it would eventually connect to New York State Route 208 (NY 208). This route replaced what was planned as a part of Route 3 in 1927 between Paterson and Greenwood Lake. By the time the route was renumbered to Route 208 in 1953 to match NY 208
column4: only a portion of the route in Fair Lawn from Route 4 to Maple Avenue had been built. Route 208 was completed west to U.S. Route 202 (US 202) in Oakland by 1960 as a two-lane undivided road; it would be built into its present configuration in later years. A Route 208 freeway was planned across the Ramapo Mountains from Oakland to connect to a proposed NY 208 freeway at Greenwood Lake; however
column5: it was never built. After I-287 was extended from Montville to the New York border in 1993
column6: it took over the alignment of Route 208 between US 202 and the route’s current northern terminus. The last traffic signal along Route 208 at McBride Avenue was removed in 1995 and the interchange with Route 4 and Saddle River Road was reconstructed in 2002."

column1: 1520;Fear
column2: The (1995);"Fear is a feeling induced by perceived danger or threat that occurs in certain types of organisms
column3: which causes a change in metabolic and organ functions and ultimately a change in behavior
column4: such as fleeing
column5: hiding
column6: or freezing from perceived traumatic events. Fear in human beings may occur in response to a specific stimulus occurring in the present
column7: or in anticipation or expectation of a future threat perceived as a risk to body or life. The fear response arises from the perception of danger leading to confrontation with or escape from/avoiding the threat (also known as the fight-or-flight response)
column8: which in extreme cases of fear (horror and terror) can be a freeze response or paralysis.

column1: In humans and animals
column2: fear is modulated by the process of cognition and learning. Thus fear is judged as rational or appropriate and irrational or inappropriate. An irrational fear is called a phobia.

column1: Psychologists such as John B. Watson
column2: Robert Plutchik
column3: and Paul Ekman have suggested that there is only a small set of basic or innate emotions and that fear is one of them. This hypothesized set includes such emotions as acute stress reaction
column4: anger
column5: angst
column6: anxiety
column7: fright
column8: horror
column9: joy
column10: panic
column11: and sadness. Fear is closely related to
column14: which occurs as the result of threats that are perceived to be uncontrollable or unavoidable. The fear response serves survival by generating appropriate behavioral responses
column15: so it has been preserved throughout evolution."

column1: 1522;Trial by Jury (1994);"A jury trial
column2: or trial by jury
column3: is a legal proceeding in which a jury makes a decision or findings of fact
column4: which then direct the actions of a judge. It is distinguished from a bench trial in which a judge or panel of judges makes all decisions.

column1: Jury trials are used in a significant share of serious criminal cases in almost all common law legal systems (Singapore
column2: for example
column3: is an exception)
column4: and juries or lay judges have been incorporated into the legal systems of many civil law countries for criminal cases. Only the United States makes routine use of jury trials in a wide variety of non-criminal cases. Other common law legal jurisdictions use jury trials only in a very select class of cases that make up a tiny share of the overall civil docket (like defamation suits in England and Wales)
column5: but true civil jury trials are almost entirely absent elsewhere in the world. Some civil law jurisdictions
column6: however
column7: have arbitration panels where non-legally trained members decide cases in select subject-matter areas relevant to the arbitration panel members' areas of expertise.

column1: The availability of a trial by jury in American jurisdictions varies. Because the United States legal system separated from that of the English one at American Revolution
column2: the types of proceedings that use juries depends on whether such cases were tried by jury under English common law at that time rather than the methods used in English courts now. For example
column3: at the time
column4: English ""courts of law"" tried cases of torts or private law for monetary damages using juries
column5: but ""courts of equity"" that tried civil cases seeking an injunction or another form of non-monetary relief did not. As a result
column6: this practice continues in American civil laws
column7: but in modern English law
column8: only criminal proceedings and some inquests are likely to be heard by a jury.

column1: The use of jury trials
column2: which evolved within common law systems rather than civil law systems
column3: has had a profound impact on the nature of American civil procedure and criminal procedure rules
column4: even if a bench trial is actually contemplated in a particular case. In general
column5: the availability of a jury trial if properly demanded has given rise to a system in which fact finding is concentrated in a single trial rather than multiple hearings
column6: and appellate review of trial court decisions is greatly limited. Jury trials are of far less importance (or of no importance) in countries that do not have a common law system."

column1: 1539;Being Human (1993);"Modern humans (Homo sapiens
column2: primarily ssp. Homo sapiens sapiens) are the only extant members of Hominina tribe (or human tribe)
column3: a branch of the tribe Hominini belonging to the family of great apes. They are characterized by erect posture and bipedal locomotion; high manual dexterity and heavy tool use compared to other animals; and a general trend toward larger
column4: more complex brains and societies.

column1: Early hominins—particularly the australopithecines
column2: whose brains and anatomy are in many ways more similar to ancestral non-human apes—are less often referred to as ""human"" than hominins of the genus Homo. Several of these hominins used fire
column3: occupied much of Eurasia
column4: and gave rise to anatomically modern Homo sapiens in Africa about 200
column5: 000 years ago. They began to exhibit evidence of behavioral modernity around 50
column6: 000 years ago. In several waves of migration
column7: anatomically modern humans ventured out of Africa and populated most of the world.

column1: The spread of humans and their large and increasing population has had a profound impact on large areas of the environment and millions of native species worldwide. Advantages that explain this evolutionary success include a relatively larger brain with a particularly well-developed neocortex
column2: prefrontal cortex and temporal lobes
column3: which enable high levels of abstract reasoning
column4: language
column5: problem solving
column6: sociality
column7: and culture through social learning. Humans use tools to a much higher degree than any other animal
column8: are the only extant species known to build fires and cook their food
column9: and are the only extant species to clothe themselves and create and use numerous other technologies and arts.

column1: Humans are uniquely adept at utilizing systems of symbolic communication (such as language and art) for self-expression and the exchange of ideas
column2: and for organizing themselves into purposeful groups. Humans create complex social structures composed of many cooperating and competing groups
column3: from families and kinship networks to political states. Social interactions between humans have established an extremely wide variety of values
column4: social norms
column5: and rituals
column6: which together form the basis of human society. Curiosity and the human desire to understand and influence the environment and to explain and manipulate phenomena (or events) has provided the foundation for developing science
column7: philosophy
column8: mythology
column9: religion
column10: anthropology
column11: and numerous other fields of knowledge.

column1: Though most of human existence has been sustained by hunting and gathering in band societies
column2: increasing numbers of human societies began to practice sedentary agriculture approximately some 10
column3: 000 years ago
column4: domesticating plants and animals
column5: thus allowing for the growth of civilization. These human societies subsequently expanded in size
column6: establishing various forms of government
column7: religion
column8: and culture around the world
column9: unifying people within regions to form states and empires. The rapid advancement of scientific and medical understanding in the 19th and 20th centuries led to the development of fuel-driven technologies and increased lifespans
column10: causing the human population to rise exponentially. Today the global human population is estimated by the United Nations to be near 7.5 billion."

column1: 1554;Safe Passage (1994);Operations Safe Haven and Safe Passage (Sept. 8 1994-March 15
column2: 1995) were operations by the United States Joint Task Force designed to relieve the overcrowded migrant camps at Guantanamo Bay Naval Base. Safe Haven established four camps on Empire Range
column3: Panama to provide a safe haven for up to ten thousand Cuban migrants. Safe Passage then returned the migrants to Guantanamo after the crowded conditions could be alleviated. These migrants had attempted to enter the United States illegally by crossing the Florida Straits in the summer of 1994. The operation was conducted under the command of General Barry McCaffrey and the direction of Clinton administration. [1]

column1: Operation Safe Haven began in September 1994
column2: when the first Cubans arrived in Panama from Guantanamo. Camps were established in Panama as a result of an agreement between the US and Panamanian governments that permitted the Cubans to remain in Panama for six months. Cuban migrants continued to arrive until the camps reached their peak occupancy of 8
column3: 600. Of these 8
column5: approximately 1
column6: 280 Cubans entered the United States in mid-October 1994 as a result of a program of parole entry by the US Department of Justice. In addition
column7: 110 Cubans were accepted by Spain
column8: and 10 by Venezuela.

column1: Due in part to uncertainly about their future
column2: some of the Cuban migrants became increasingly restless as the weeks went by. The growing tension led to disturbances and riots on December 7–8
column4: which were quickly controlled by US military members. During the riots

column6: including the destruction of various military vehicles
column7: computers
column8: and telephones. After the riots took place a fifth camp was established to house the leaders of the riots and any individual who seemed a threat. Camp five housed both men and women. It also contained a high security jail system that placed individuals into individual cells. 5th Bn 87th Infantry Fort Davis Panama
column9: was the primary US Army unit conducting security operations and bore the brunt of the riots. Camp five was manned by Air Force Security Police from the 17th SPS Goodfellow A.F.B. San Angelo
column10: Texas. Other personnel there was the 2nd Rangers and 194th Army Military Police of the 101st ABN (AASLT) division.

column1: As the expiration of the US-Panamanian agreement permitting the Cubans to stay in Panama approached
column2: planning began for Operation Safe Passage—the return of the Cubans to Guantanamo Bay Naval Facility. Between February 1
column4: and February 20
column7: 300 Cubans were transported from Panama to Guantanamo Naval Base. The mission of the transfer operation was to move the Cuban migrants from Safe Haven camps in Panama to Guantanamo in a safe
column8: orderly manner.[2]"

column1: 1559;Hostile Intentions (1994);"Hostile attribution bias
column2: or hostile attribution of intent
column3: is the tendency to interpret others' behaviors as having hostile intent
column4: even when the behavior is ambiguous or benign. For example
column5: a person with high levels of hostile attribution bias might see two people laughing and immediately interpret this behavior as two people laughing about him/her
column6: even though the behavior was ambiguous and may have been benign.

column1: The term ""hostile attribution bias"" was first coined in 1980 by Nasby
column2: Hayden
column3: and DePaulo who noticed
column4: along with several other key pioneers in this research area (e.g.
column5: Kenneth Dodge)
column6: that a subgroup of children tend to attribute hostile intent to ambiguous social situations more often than other children. Since then
column7: hostile attribution bias has been conceptualized as a bias of social information processing (similar to other attribution biases)
column8: including the way individuals perceive
column9: interpret
column10: and select responses to situations. While occasional hostile attribution bias is normative (particularly for younger children)
column11: researchers have found that individuals who exhibit consistent and high levels of hostile attribution bias across development are much more likely to engage in aggressive behavior (e.g.
column14: verbal or relational aggression) toward others.

column1: In addition
column2: hostile attribution bias is hypothesized to be one important pathway through which other risk factors
column3: such as peer rejection or harsh parenting behavior
column4: lead to aggression. For example
column5: children exposed to peer teasing at school or child abuse at home are much more likely to develop high levels of hostile attribution bias
column6: which then lead them to behave aggressively at school and/or at home. Thus
column7: in addition to partially explaining one way aggression develops
column8: hostile attribution bias also represents a target for the intervention and prevention of aggressive behaviors."

column1: 1616;Desert Winds (1995);"A desert is a barren area of land where little precipitation occurs and consequently living conditions are hostile for plant and animal life. The lack of vegetation exposes the unprotected surface of the ground to the processes of denudation. About one third of the land surface of the world is arid or semi-arid. This includes much of the polar regions where little precipitation occurs and which are sometimes called polar deserts or ""cold deserts"". Deserts can be classified by the amount of precipitation that falls
column2: by the temperature that prevails
column3: by the causes of desertification or by their geographical location.

column1: Deserts are formed by weathering processes as large variations in temperature between day and night put strains on the rocks which consequently break in pieces. Although rain seldom occurs in deserts
column2: there are occasional downpours that can result in flash floods. Rain falling on hot rocks can cause them to shatter and the resulting fragments and rubble strewn over the desert floor is further eroded by the wind. This picks up particles of sand and dust and wafts them aloft in sand or dust storms. Wind-blown sand grains striking any solid object in their path can abrade the surface. Rocks are smoothed down
column3: and the wind sorts sand into uniform deposits. The grains end up as level sheets of sand or are piled high in billowing sand dunes. Other deserts are flat
column4: stony plains where all the fine material has been blown away and the surface consists of a mosaic of smooth stones. These areas are known as desert pavements and little further erosion takes place. Other desert features include rock outcrops
column5: exposed bedrock and clays once deposited by flowing water. Temporary lakes may form and salt pans may be left when waters evaporate. There may be underground sources of water in the form of springs and seepages from aquifers. Where these are found
column6: oases can occur.

column1: Plants and animals living in the desert need special adaptations to survive in the harsh environment. Plants tend to be tough and wiry with small or no leaves
column2: water-resistant cuticles and often spines to deter herbivory. Some annual plants germinate
column3: bloom and die in the course of a few weeks after rainfall while other long-lived plants survive for years and have deep root systems able to tap underground moisture. Animals need to keep cool and find enough food and water to survive. Many are nocturnal and stay in the shade or underground during the heat of the day. They tend to be efficient at conserving water
column4: extracting most of their needs from their food and concentrating their urine. Some animals remain in a state of dormancy for long periods
column5: ready to become active again when the rare rains fall. They then reproduce rapidly while conditions are favorable before returning to dormancy.

column1: People have struggled to live in deserts and the surrounding semi-arid lands for millennia. Nomads have moved their flocks and herds to wherever grazing is available and oases have provided opportunities for a more settled way of life. The cultivation of semi-arid regions encourages erosion of soil and is one of the causes of increased desertification. Desert farming is possible with the aid of irrigation and the Imperial Valley in California provides an example of how previously barren land can be made productive by the import of water from an outside source. Many trade routes have been forged across deserts
column2: especially across the Sahara Desert
column3: and traditionally were used by caravans of camels carrying salt
column4: gold
column5: ivory and other goods. Large numbers of slaves were also taken northwards across the Sahara. Some mineral extraction also takes place in deserts and the uninterrupted sunlight gives potential for the capture of large quantities of solar energy."

A panel of sportswriters and broadcasters from throughout the United States and Canada votes on the recipient. Each judge casts a vote for first
column3: second and third place selections. Each first-place vote is worth five points; each second-place vote is worth three points; and each third-place vote is worth one point. The player with the highest point total
column4: regardless of the number of first-place votes
column5: wins the award. To be eligible for the award
column6: a player must come off the bench in more games than he starts.

column1: Since its inception
column2: the award has been given to 26 different players. The most recent recipient is Jamal Crawford
column3: who has won the award three times. Kevin McHale

McHale and Bill Walton are the only Hall of Famers who have won the award; Walton is also the only award winner to have earned NBA MVP honors in their career.

column1: 1661;New Age
column2: The (1994);"The New Age is a term applied to a range of spiritual or religious beliefs and practices that developed in Western nations during the 1970s. Precise scholarly definitions of the New Age differ in their emphasis
column3: largely as a result of its highly eclectic structure. Although analytically often considered to be religious
column4: those involved in it typically prefer the designation of ""spiritual"" and rarely use the term ""New Age"" themselves. Many scholars of the subject refer to it as the New Age movement
column5: although others contest this term and suggest that it is better seen as a milieu or zeitgeist.

column1: As a form of Western esotericism
column2: the New Age drew heavily upon a number of older esoteric traditions
column3: in particular those that emerged from the occultist current that developed in the eighteenth century. Such prominent occult influences include the work of Emanuel Swedenborg and Franz Mesmer
column4: as well as the ideas of Spiritualism
column5: New Thought
column6: and Theosophy. A number of mid-twentieth century influences
column7: such as the UFO religions of the 1950s
column8: the Counterculture of the 1960s
column9: and the Human Potential Movement
column10: also exerted a strong influence on the early development of the New Age. Although the exact origins of the phenomenon remain contested
column11: it is agreed that it developed in the 1970s
column12: at which time it was centred largely in the United Kingdom. It expanded and grew largely in the 1980s and 1990s
column13: in particular within the United States. By the start of the 21st century
column14: the term ""New Age"" was increasingly rejected within this milieu
column15: with some scholars arguing that the New Age phenomenon had ended.

column1: Despite its highly eclectic nature
column2: a number of beliefs commonly found within the New Age have been identified. Theologically
column3: the New Age typically adopts a belief in a holistic form of divinity which imbues all of the universe
column4: including human beings themselves. There is thus a strong emphasis on the spiritual authority of the self. This is accompanied by a common belief in a wide variety of semi-divine non-human entities
column5: such as angels and masters
column6: with whom humans can communicate
column7: particularly through the form of channeling. Typically viewing human history as being divided into a series of distinct ages
column8: a common New Age belief is that whereas once humanity lived in an age of great technological advancement and spiritual wisdom
column9: it has entered a period of spiritual degeneracy
column10: which will be remedied through the establishment of a coming Age of Aquarius
column11: from which the milieu gets its name. There is also a strong focus on healing
column12: particularly using forms of alternative medicine
column13: and an emphasis on a ""New Age science"" which seeks to unite science and spirituality.

column1: Those involved in the New Age have been primarily from middle and upper-middle-class backgrounds. The degree to which New Agers are involved in the milieu varied considerably
column2: from those who adopted a number of New Age ideas and practices to those who fully embraced and dedicated their lives to it. The New Age has generated criticism from established Christian organisations as well as modern Pagan and indigenous communities. From the 1990s onward
column3: the New Age became the subject of research by academic scholars of religious studies."

column1: 1669;MURDER and murder (1996);"A murder is the unlawful killing of another human without justification or valid excuse
column2: especially the unlawful killing of another human being with malice aforethought. This state of mind may
column3: depending upon the jurisdiction
column4: distinguish murder from other forms of unlawful homicide
